reviewText: Its definetly a fun game. I have not finished yet because I am not on speed like others who finish it in 15 hours but they have a point. It is relatively short, however its got so many side quests and collectibles You'll be playing it for a while. And keep in mind its not meant to be a full game. Its a stand-alone DLC for the fourth. So some things will be cut out. And to be honest, I don't mind not having the customization of vehicles too much, but the radio was nice because you could listen to classical music while running people over. It was funny. And speaking of funny, the game is funny and has very witty remarks to things. They even bring people back from older games such as Dex, The ultor boss guy (I haven't played the second. I have it on steam but I mainly played the third on xbox), and those twins (Once again, haven't played second or first). This game is unique in the way you don't do missions like in the others (You know the ones I mean), instead, you cause hell to ♥♥♥♥ off satan. Then you finally face off against him to rescue the president. I honestly reccomend this game.

reviewText: Everything Saints Row stripped down to its bones. Gat out of Hell doesn't contain traditional missions like the other games in the series instead you'll be playing the side missions such as insurance fraud, survival, and a few new ones (nothing particularly groundbreaking) in Hell its self this time around. While playing this game you could beat it in about 4-5 hours of doing the same mini-games over and over. I couldn't recommend this game at its 20$ price point or really in general but if you find it on sale for half that and you got some money to spend or you enjoy the mini missions of Saints Row and its universe then by all means try it out.

reviewText:
I do not recommend Saints Row: Gat out of Hell.

I was highly anticipating this game. I pre-ordered it for $20, and I was fully aware that this was intended to be a stand-alone DLC/Game. However, the moment I start the game up, we get a cut-scene where the president, while aboard the Alien Ship, has a birthday party where a Ouija Board is found. The board sucks the President into hell, whereupon Kenzie and Gat immediately go after him to retrieve him. That was a 5 minute Cut-scene. After you get to Hell, you immediately get a car, drive to a waypoint, and you get ANOTHER cut-scene explaining why this has happened. THEN YOU GET WINGS!! You get to fly for 1 second in the beginning. You also immediately get super-speed and super jump, instead of earning it like in Saints Row 4. Your goal is to acquire the help of 4 main forces in the section of Hell you're in; Blackbeard, the Twins from Saints Row the Third, Shakespeare, and one other person. I played for 20 minutes, and I accidentally found my way to Blackbeard, where I had to help him with a STUPID RAT INFESTATION!! After 3 minutes of trying to shoot these things, Blackbeard pulls out a Hammer that does shockwaves. Why the hell didn't he  use it before?? I couldn't do it. I could not.

If this review helps you, then good. If you still plan on getting it, then I hope you have a higher tolerance then I do.

3/10. I wish I got a refund, but the option wasn't available at the time.

reviewText:
After playing the game and finish the story in about 3 - 4 hours. I have very mix feeling about the game.

It still the same gameplay as SR4 which is a good thing. New map broken into 5 area. Some new powers. 7 deadly sins guns are fun...... If you can find them. Which I feel is a bad thing. No real story mission. You just go off doing the activites  and when you finish enough of them. You get a cutscene and teleport back to your starting base. These happens 3 times and then you fight satan. Which is a very disappointing boss battle.

They did some changes to the jump/glide power to make flight. Which is very buggy. Randomly falling out of the sky. Touching a building can have you spinning out of control or teleporting around the map. Weak tell you hit get to a high enough level to get flying to almost stop draining your stam. Which at that point you have to worry about SAM sights.

I enjoyed the game but it is so short and almost no replay vaule. I would say wait to get it on sale.

reviewText:
Saints Row: Gat out of Hell

It's a great game for the price but it only has 5 story missions and practically an entire video games worth of reused mini-games also there is zero customization in the game but I guess it's pretty cool to play as Jonny Gat and Kinzie Kensington for the first time. I would also like to say that most of the story comes from the first cut scene in the game and most all of the other story parts are shown with crapy pop up book style scene, thing. all and all this game is worth it as a $10-$20 game so I would get it if you are a fan of the Saints Row games.

Final Rating: 6/10

reviewText: The game is decent, but I cannot recommend buying it at full price. Everything feels rushed, especially the final boss battle. reviewText: Saints Row: Gat out of Hell is fun. It's an expansion on SR IV so it's not too too long but it is fun. Yes, it has all the same elements of IV but you get to play in HELL! reviewText: I love Saints Row 3 and 4, that being said, i don't know what to really think about this game. I enjoyed it for the cutscenes and the musical number made me laugh loud because it came so unexpected and was just awesome.\n\nThe general gameplay though is simply minigames, some are known from the previous game like Mayhem others have changed a bit like Blazing which is now Hellblazing. There are new wacky weapons in the form of the 7 Deadly Sins" which are lot of fun and the narration and the cutscenes are amazing
date: even better than in SR4 and meeting old "friends" is always great.\n\nStill
recommended: it just feels like there could've been so much more. "Saints Row V - Saints go to Hell" is what comes to my mind. All the Saints in Hell fighting against Satan while meeting evil people from earth's History while pulling one-liners.  Here instead we meet Vlad the Impaler in a Prison that looks like a Kindergarten with children's music and it's fun - especially when you let the music go for a while
hoursPlayed: with Vlad begging you to stop it. But that's all you get from him. The loyalty mission is just a bunch of mini games stringed together and afterwards
voteText: you never see him again. There's a ton of potential in this setting that Volition ignored because it's just a small stand alone expansion.\n\nThe biggest minus is the lack of music. You hear music in buildings like the Nightclub with DJ Shakespeare but there are no radio stations and nothing going one while you collect clusters to upgrade your superpowers. Music made that exercise fun in SR4
helpfulPercent: here it becomes a burden - unless you put on some music outside the game. SR4 music works great
votesHelpful: i did a Mayhem mission with Mötley Crüe's Shout at the Devil
votesTotal: which works just great.\n\nAll in all i was entertained (so a thumbs up because i knew it would be a short game)
votesFunny: the cutscenes are fun and unexpected
commentsCount: the Gat & Kinzie Team works great since they're different character wise and they make that clear in the first few minutes. Still i think the scenario is wasted on such a short (5 hours for me without doing all the same mini games over and over again 20 times) game. I want Saints in Hell with Pierce singing Meat Loafs Bat out of Hell with the player character!"

reviewText: I'm torn on how I should grade this. Does it get a good grade if you're able to get it cheap thanks to the $5 Gamestop preorder offer or do I mark it down for what it's available at now? Ultimately I have to review this based on what the average consumer is getting now and Gat out of Hell is simply not worth the asking price. There's no story missions, no crazy cutscenes and vehicles are once again useless.\n\nThe gameplay however is the same Saint's Row 4 goodness (but a lot lighter in terms of content) with a revised flight system that I really enjoyed and it made the collectible hunt a lot more interesting. If you absolutely need more Saint's Row, you're going to like this. But otherwise I would wait for the eventual sale when it's down to $5 or $10 (which is pushing it.)

reviewText:
The game has far too many bugs. Ranging from getting stuck on the loading screen, to getting a character stuck in some kind of frozen motion. I have to check the validity of the game package every time I start it now, because otherwise it might not load my save games. This game on SteamOS is a serious miss. I don't know if these bugs affect other platforms, but I would check before purchasing.

Other than that the content is just confusing. There isn't much of a story to tell playing it other than just goofing off with weapons, vehicles and Saints powers in a hell themed city. There isn't really a logic to it. It isn't like Grand Theft Auto, where there's an actual story that you can follow.

I guess you could say the only plus is the humor side of it, but I'm still not really laughing so I don't know. Don't bother unless the game is in the 5$ range.

reviewText: This is my first negative review to a game and what makes it feel even worse is that I'm a fan of Saints Row series. This game is essentially a huge hand job to Johnny Gat and his fans, so if you're into Gat this game is deffinetely for you. I honsetly don't know if people really like Gat that much or if the devs do, so I can't really tell if this is fan service or a fetish game. Although, I haven't played the first 2 Saints Row games yet, so maybe I'm just missing something. But anyway, the other playable charecter is Kinzie, who barely even pops up in the cutscenes regardless if you're playing as her or not, she was likely included in the game just because having two Gats in multiplayer wouldn't make much sense. Also worth noting is that the game completely lacks any sort of charecter or vehicle costumization, which was a huge part of the charm of Saits Row games. The campaign is painfully short, you can easily complete it in under 4 hours while getting distracted by all the collectables. Gat out of Hell doesn't have as much of a Saints Rowish atmosphere" as the other games did

reviewText: The core gameplay and city design of Gat out of Hell are far superior to Saints Row 4, thanks to the world being tailor-made for the game's super powers and a flight system that feels great when zipping through the narrow passages of New Hades. Sadly, it almost feels a shame for these great additions to be confined to such a scaled back entry in the franchise, with no real quests or character development of note, and a much smaller selection of gear at your disposal. That being said, the game is still worth the asking price, and a great excuse to engage in more mindless Saints Row action.

reviewText: I was in the middle of writing a full on review, and Steam automatically restarted and I lost everything. I don't feel like typing it all again so I'm going to keep this short:\n\nMediocre at best. ZERO customization (unless you buy the pack that lets you have purple wings, whoopdefriggindoo), all shops have been replaced by a vending machine which only lets you buy/upgrade your weapons. The weapons are mostly average accept for the armchair, which is pretty decent. I really only ever found the stomp power useful, the rest I barely touched. The map is fairly small, the activities are sub-par, the musical number gave me a headache, and the whole watered down story is told through a storybook style narration. Six different endings, so that's cool I suppose, it's the only thing that adds any form of replay value to the game. You DO get to shoot Satan in the face, so there's that. I'd pass on this one unless you can get it on sale for about $5.

reviewText:
I really like this series.  I've played through and beaten every one of them.  I like the story, I like the characters, I like the gameplay.  Unfortunately, I don't like this game.

My biggest complaints about SR3 and SR4 were 'if you want my character to act like Jonny Gat, just let me play as Jonny Gat.'  Well, here you go.  You're Jonny Gat (or Kenzie Kensington, if you prefer), off to save the boss.  The story seems like typical SR stuff, which is to say that it's brimming with absurdity.  All of the typical Saints Row flavor is mostly present, but this game really feels rough.  There are some parts that are just really choppy for no apparent reason, especially considering earlier iterations of this franchise had identical or similar mechanics that just worked better.  Combat pretty much sucks.  Melee finishers have this earlier-mentioned choppiness problem, and gunplay feels unsatisfying.  There's nothing really new here in terms of gameplay either, it's just more Saints Row IV but with a different environment, which coincidentally makes it feel like a janky version of Crackdown, not just in feel, but in style.

I can't reccomend this game at it's full retail price, and I really can't move past a 'well, if you've got nothing else to do' reccomendation on this title even if it's on sale.  If you're a diehard Saints Row fan, there might be something here for you but if you've never played a game in this franchise but are considering this one, skip it, spend a couple extra dollars and give SR3 or SR4 a shot instead, which are both more enjoyable games.  For that matter, 1 is probably better, because it does a better job being a GTA clone than this game does as a Crackdown one.

reviewText:
To be brutally honest...

Ｉｔ’ｓ ｆｕｃｋｉｎｇ ｓｈｉｔ.

I was extremely excited for this game before it came out, because it had SO MUCH ♥♥♥♥ING POTENTIAL. I mean after all, you are playing as JOHNNY MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING GAT, but playing it just made me sad. It's nothing but a money making racket and not worth €20. That said, if you can grab it for a low price go ahead and try it, but I doubt you'll even finish it without getting bored.

reviewText:
Avoid this at all cost! Do not buy this! Not worth the prize at all. It's way overpriced for such short and trashy standalone dlc. This is not even for the most hardcore Saints Row fans. Story took 3 hours to complete and felt very underwealming. Add couple hours in if you want to complete every mission and collect all the stuff.

The game is too easy. Missions are boring and there is little to no varierity. Music is boring and forgettable. Hell is boring all around. Everything feels soulless. The writing is level of a bad fan fiction that makes you chuckle here and there once or twice if you try hard enough. Gat and Kinzie have never felt this boring and unlikeable ever. You just keep asking to yourself why can't you play as your own boss the whole time...

Only goods things ares Satan's singing voice but you can just go check the musical trailer in YouTube. And another fun things is flying with the wings. Otherwise it's just a bad reskin of SR4. And instead of aliens, you fight against demons that all look the same and have no personality. So does the 'citizens' as well who are just these dull grey ghouls.

I had to force myself to play through to see the ending but that was very disappointing too and not worth playing through to see the alternative endings. This left a really bad taste in my mouth and I hope the devs take break from SR franchice for couple years and come back with fresh new ideas and locations instead of this garbage.

Biggest dissapointment in this franchice so far.

reviewText: There were a few laughs. But $20 is an awful lot to ask for 5 minutes worth of cutscenes and a level reskin. reviewText: Saints Row: Gat out of Hell is solid stand alone expnansion for Saints Row IV. The gameplay is generally the same; use super powers to take down enemies, cause destruction and all that nonsensical fun. The new locale is Hell, though it's just Steelport reconfigured to look like Hell. They do it well enough that it feels somewhat new though so that is also nice. What really shines above all else in this game is the power of flight. The ability to fly really increases the freedom of the game and makes it even more fun. However, all this aside, Saints Row: Gat out of Hell lacks the personality that IV developed. While you can play Gat or Kenzie, they don't have many lines recorded from them and there are no customizations for them, not even clothing. It may seem unnecessary to quibble over something as that, but the customizabble asthetic is what gave Saints Row it's extra personality.\n\nOverall, Gat out of Hell is a good game if you enjoyed Saints Row IV. The game's storyline is mostly all activities, but the activities are a bit more fun than IV. I'd say it's definately worth the 20 price tag if you enjoyed IV, otherwise I'd say you might wanna pass on it until a price drop.

reviewText:
Gat Out of Hell? Oh boy. I have a few words for this game.
My friend and I pre-ordered this game, because we loved the other games. Saints Row 3 was a fantastic game and Saints Row 4 was also pretty enjoyable. However, when I played for about half an hour, I set down my controller and never touched the game since.
You can show me my character from the last game, then you just take him away. They removed physical stores with vending machines, they removed character customization, they removed car customization, gun styles, cheats, opening release DLCs, and now we have a smaller map.
I want a refund and a better, because I wasted $20 dollars on this game.
So, to those reading this, there are better games out there. Just keep looking.

reviewText:
At it's current price of $20, I would never recommend you to buy this. In the five hours I have played this game, I have beaten the game and collected about 80% of the collectibles, all of which playing on the hardest difficulty.

It still looks like Saints Row and is full of comedic value that the series is known for, but it doesn't feel like Saints Row anymore. It may be just me but going through the story, I feel the voice actors and dialouge just feels out of it; the setting is getting tired and old as it takes place in Steelport, yet again; the only difference now is a different color filter and floating islands that the clusters taken from SR4 can be thrown onto.

As for gameplay, if you've played SR4, Gat out of Hell is more the same, except now you can fly with wings. Same movement powers, same attack powers, (slam, blast, etc.) same upgrades, really just the same of everything. The only real exception from this to SR4 is that guns are different. Gone is the Dubstep gun and to replace it, they added seven unique weapons to fill each weapon type that coorelate to seven sins, which were nice to unlock.

Overall, don't bother spending $20 on this unless you're a diehard fan for there simply is not enough content to warrant it. The story can be beaten in a good hour or two and getting all of the collectibles would probably take the same amount of time.

reviewText:
Depressingly disappointing diatribe of disingenuous dilly-dallying dictated by droll, dolorous and devolved direction.

Translation; was not as enjoyable as it could have been.

It has the charm of the previous Saints games (specifically SR3 and SR4), and points of it were fun. Flying around on flaming angel wings before slamming into the ground, throwing imps at people and smiting them with the hammer of god was fun the first time.

And then that was it.

The game does not have a storyline; it has side missions stapled onto static cutscenes. Think Diablo 3's intermission cutscenes, but instead of character dialogue, you had the general quest text from WoW or something. And at least WoW had coherent storylines.

The weapons were limited and rather unimpressive. A Lay-Z-Boy with twin chainguns and rocket launchers sounds awesome, but its execution is... lacking.

And of course, the best scenes in the game are reserved for computer-generated awesome"

reviewText:
When reviewing a game, the question isn't whether you had fun. I did have fun playing this game, I even feel like I got my money's worth, but I just couldn't reccomend it at the $20 price point. There are a lot of good games at or below that price (most notably, Saint's Row 3 and 4), that will give you a lot more enjoyment for your dollar than will Gat Out Of Hell. There are three places where this installment just doesn't live up to it's price tag: the length of the game, the features in the game, and the scope of the game.

First, this game is really short. It's not terribly short as DLC goes, but like I said above, there are lots of full games for $20 with significantly more content. I had beaten the story missions in about five hours playing at a liesurely pace, taking time to fly around, getting some collectibles, and doing a few challenges. After about 11 hours I have a 99% completion, with just a few of the annoying challenges to go. Again, for DLC that isn't bad, but in context a game like Saint's Row 4 or Red Faction: Guerilla will last for weeks, and these things are the same price.

Second, this game lacks a lot of the features of previous Saint's Row games. There are no radio stations. There are no physical shops to visit. There are no character costumes or weapon skins. There are no cribs. There is no cell phone to call in support. Calling this game a DLC is a little bit misleading, because DLC expands a game you've already bought, and even if Gat Out Of Hell didn't include its own shops and costumes, an actual expansion to the game would have carried these things over from Saint's Row 4. Instead, Gat Out of Hell is actually a stripped down version of Saint's Row 4, with a new area and story, but missing many traditional Saint's Row features. If your idea of Hell is harassing the damned with the Violator, while dressed as a genki girl... well too bad, because you can't do that here.

Finally, this game doesn't accomplish much. The game map is pretty small, and once you get your wings and a couple upgrades it will only take you a minute or two to fly from end to end. The game doesn't really tie up any of the loose ends from Saint's Row 4, nor does it do anything for Johnny's character, as the end is too ambiguous to mean anything for the series long-term (they are also extremely unsatisfying). Neither Johnny or Kinzie grow or change as characters, despite their hellish context, which is a little bit of a let down. Kinzie might be the biggest let-down about this game for me, because I really thought that Hell would be a great place to explore her unique brand of crazy. Unfortunately, she's completely flat as a character, and it's pretty obvious that despite being a playable character, she got very little attention. Johnny is much funnier and fleshed out in this adventure, as well as reacting more authentically to being in Hell.

I got this game for $20, and I thought it was worth it just being big fan of the Saint's Row games and the developer Volition, but I can't really recommend it. If you've played all of the Saint's Row games and you're just itching for more, then you should pick up Gat Out Of Hell. If you haven't played Saint's Row Before, you should pick up Saint's Row 3 and 4 before playing this. There are just too many great games out there for $20 to justify buying this for the story or gameplay.

reviewText:
Wow, ok after weeks of this not working, for some reason it magically worked fine with no problem. So I played it til I beat it. It took literally 3 hours to do all the missions and side quests. I got a 65% completion and I know the other 35% is collectables and activities I didn't get gold on. My only main complaint is that there's this activity called Hellblazing. It's exactly like it's older incarnations in 3 and 4 but it's unplayable unless you farm a ♥♥♥♥ ton of clusters and upgrade your flight. Also, in the older Saints Row's ou could do missions at your own pace which I really loved. This, however, does not allow that. As soon as you fill up a meter by causing carnage (which is literally the whole game), it just jumps you into the mission! What the hell?!

*spoiler* So this game has multiple endings but you are seriously only able to see one of them unless you replay (not the mission) but the whole game. WHAT. The. Hell!
So...7.2/10 too much clusters.

reviewText: What's in it is good, assuming you liked Saints Row IV, because it's more of the same.  You get super powers, flight, super speed, and the same four basic special abilites as in the previous entry to the series.  Only difference is now it's arcane rather than Matrix-ey stuff.  You do the normal saints row things - time trial races, blow up fences, ragdoll in traffic, et cetera - and then after you complete about half the available activities the ending becomes available and then you're done. I beat the game in 3 hours, not 100% mind, but that would at best double the play time (edit: 7:55, 97%, so I was a little off).\n\nIt's an example of what a good $10 DLC should be, unfortunately it's a $20 standalone game.  If you're interested, buy it when it's on sale.  Otherwise save your money for the inevitable Saints Row V and/or reboot of the series.

reviewText:
SR: Gat out of Hell is extremely short with it only taking 3 hours to get up to the final boss... Taking you up to a further 5 hours for full takeover, however after that you have challenges and collectibles. The one reason I continued playing this game was to collect all the collectibles. Once you collect one, you can't stop the rampage as you start flying through the map on a collecting spree...

Enough of that... SR: GooH is a standalone expansion for the superhero expansion of SR, SR 4. A very short expansion however you will find yourself having so much fun as you sit in your comfy chair, blasting rockets at the countless demons. The weapons feel fresh and new as you collect the 7 deadly sins, which are epic in their own little way. The game is practically end game SR where you going around completing all the diversions and finishing off activities which tbh can be a bit grindy as there is only 4 different minigames as the game focuses more on one-off diversions such as Spires and Extraction Facilities.

Despite the grindy nature of this expansion, GooH introduces a new map, Hell, which consists of 5 different areas (6 counting the tower) which can be traversed using the new fly ability which is far superior compared to SR4's glide. Mentioning abilities, Blast, Stomp and Aura all return from the last game (They have different elements howeveR) but Telekenisis is replaced by my new favourite, Summon, which allows you to spawn in little imps, towers or a big legionaire (which is quite good). The game has few good quests, with the Upgrading Halo one and Final Battle really only being the unique quests.

Instead of playing as the Saints Boss, you play as Johnny Gat and Kinzie Kensington, both characters are good picks by the developers. However, character customization is completely removed (not even the ability to change your clothes) though players can find 30 amusing commentaries for both the characters

Summary
Soundtrack 5/10 No radio stations???
Gameplay 9/10 -1 point for grinding and unispiring missions
Story 8/10 Reintroducing the DeWynters and Dane as main characters were good, but they needed more time in the spotlight.
Graphics 10/10 Despite there being a lot of red, the graphics were perfect, can't really complete, I guess it is hell

reviewText:
This game is an excelent expansion to saints row 4, with a good plot, interesting twist on the old side activities and refreshing new powers. The story is light hearted and enjoyable, keeping with the over the top comedy that makes the saints row franchise so enjoyable. The game play expands on the superpowers that you get in SR4 with theme appropriate alterations such as demon summoning and worship aura. I love the new flying mechanics, in my opinion it is an improvement from the last games gliding system. Bonus: you get to play as Gat or Kinzie, as much as I love the character I have made since SR1 its really cool stepping out of their shoes. Its also nice that they brought back some of the old NPCs from previous games. It should be said that this is more of an expansion than a stand alone game. I had fun playing it but it only took me 7.5 hours to beat the story, complete all side activities, fully power up my character, and find all collectables, which is actually pretty good. In previous games it sometimes felt like a chore to get gold in every activity, or even to complete every activity, but in this game they didn't over do it.

TL;DR Game is short but good, I had lots of fun playing it and highly recommend it.
Edit: Spoiler alert




Nathan Fillion is God

reviewText:
To put it short, it's nothing but mini games and is missing that Saints Row comedy we know and love.
Don't bother unless it goes on sale.

To put it long...
Pros:
-It looks pretty damn cool. And is still as sleazy as steelport.
-The musical number was pretty sweet.
-A chance to play as Johnny and Kinzie? Yes please.
-Bee gun.
-The arcane powers were a worthy act to follow the superpowers from SRIV. Seriously fun.
-They somehow made Fraud even more fun. Watching a shuffling husk getting hit by a car and bouncing away is just so satisfying.
-Audio logs were great.
-You basically you just have to cause as much of a scene to get Satans attention. You didn't ever have to follow the objectives to do so. Just play minigames. Not sure if this is a pro or con.

Cons:
-There's only 3 story based missions. The rest of the game is just rehashed minigames.
-Could of used more old Saints Row characters. I didn't really care for Blackbeard or whatever.
-Way too many collectables. Why collect souls when you can buy them by the bulk?
-No music and a lot of reused animations.
-Quite buggy. Often during survival minigames, enemies wouldn't spawn and I would have to restart the activity.
-Not that funny. And the funny lines were often repeated and beaten into the ground.
-Always refers to the player and the President as a he, regardless if playing as Kinzie or if you have a female boss.
-Only replayablility would be in collecting the needless amount of achievements.
-5 endings which were okay but not really needed and will probably be forgotten in Saints Row 5.
-Not worth £15. Nah.

As a fan of the Saints Row series, I was really excited for a new installment but was incredibly disapointed. I would defiently not recommend it to a non-fan. And if you are a Saints Row fan, I'd only recommend you buy it to fund the next Saints Row game. Sorry Volition, I love you but.... Please do better next time.

reviewText: SR: Gat out of Hell is more of the same game we've all come to know and love, but with enough changed to make the game feel like a genuine addition, not just a reskin with an attempt to make money before releasing a true sequel. The powers are back, but feel almost entirely different, aside from sprinting, but hey, how different can you make running, with the new flying system actually living up to its name. The flight mechanic is a big highlight in the game, with enough speed to make up for no summonable vehicles, nimble enough not to be frustrating, and just bad ♥♥♥ enough to feel satisfying using it for the majority of the short game. Guns, while limited, are still satisfying, with a few hidden gems clearly having been lovingly made. You'll love Gat and Kinzie's foray into the infernal plane if you can get past the fact that this isn't a true successor to the Saint's Row series; meaning that it's not meant to have all the bells and whistles. With Gat getting some well deserved love as well as Kinzie, this should be the balm to that itch you got from SRIV from banging your entire team.

reviewText:
Is more Saints Row really a bad thing? I don't think so.
First to just get this out of the way.  This is just a glorified DLC.  Just so there's no misconception on what's really happening.


The Good:
The powers are back and in many ways better than originally implimented in SR4 flight is a ton of fun once you get used to it.
It's still got that  Saints stupid humor.
This iteration has seemingly been built better for multiplayer including activities and missions that appear to really be better with friends.
The Meh
The activities are still repetitive mini-games.
The Ugly
Because some activties are better for co-op it makes doing them in single player more annoying than rewarding.
Territorial control seems meaningless for some reason.
Some powers feel more useless than others.
The lack of story is truely disappointing. While able to boast that there are multiple endings to the game it just doesn't have quite the same feeling of other Saints games by removing a vast majority of the cast and limiting the game to only a few core missions most of which are isolated without the banter or camaraderie it just leaves the game feeling like it's missing its heart.
Final Verdict:
I'm split on this one, for any fans of the series as a whole (not just 3 & 4) but of the whole story this could be a good value to you in spite of  it's flaws. To people who may have just started recently and not have a history with the entire series this game will probably seem like a hollow shell of a stand alone and may even sour you on the franchise. So for those of you who only recently joined I'd advise you pick it up on steam sale for cheap if you're bored.

This is fan service at it's finest to give people who consider Gat their main  man a chance to take the wheel for once instead of riding shotgun.

reviewText:
Missing the Heart of SR3

While technically this is a new, smaller, map than the last two games despite being reskinned for Hell, and looking very good in that respect, you will find many areas that feel structurally extremely similiar if not directly lifted from the previous games.

Mechanically this is a clone of SR4. Except for flight, all the powers, majority of weapons are the same exact ones you had in SR4 but instead of the source being hacking a virtual world, it is from Lucifers Halo. The names are different but functionally the same for most of them. The anti-power grenades from the previous game are back, but unexplained how it affects the supposedly most powerful artifact in the universe. Chasing down the orbs is back but now they're Sin Orbs. Once your notoriety gets high enough a boss plops down with the same hellfire rain from the last game and basically the same fight mechanics.

Unfortunately with so much same, whats different? Mostly just the look of the map and that you can play as Gat or Kinzie.  Also the introduction of flying is really cool.

But a bigger question is whats lost? For me the most important thing missing is the cultivation of the plot. Despite having some potentially really interesting characters in the game like Shakespeare & Vlad the Impaler there is almost nothing done with them. In lieu of almost any cutscenes in the game a still frame storybook device was used. So every time you expect to some really interesting interaction it cuts to the storybook and everything is summarised for you. No pop music/culture infused action moments

Also gone any type of customization. No private garages or helopads, no customizing vehicles, changing clothes, etc ...
Whereas in previous games you could pick different homies and see their different interactions with one another, you can pick no one here so thats gone. SR4 was full of celebrity homies like Roddy Piper & Keith David with fun interactions.

This is basically the most Soulless version of Saints Row out of the last 3 or more versions. Describing this as basically a collection of the mini games from previous versions is mostly correct. The battle with Satan is weak and arguably much easier than reaching max notoriety.

I recommend this game but not at full price.

Volition, High Voltage whoever is calling the shots, take some time off, take a year or two and make a next gen Saints Row. Another installment like this on an already 4+ year old game engine could sink the franchise

reviewText: It's more of the same, and that might be a good thing, if you're a fan that is.\nIt's the trademark over the top violence and goofiness that always makes me come back to the Saints row games, but this one's lacking. The gameplay is the same as in Saints row IV and it's also a direct continuation of the story. However, the story missions makes for very little content, and with the diversions I got to 100% completion in just under 18 hours.  For the price tag I guess that's what you can expect, but I'm missing that little extra bit, the one that makes me commited to a game. IV had some amazing set pieces, the wacky 1950s sitcom missions, the alien assault on the white house, fleeing the alien ship listening to eurodance one hit wonder Haddaway. I find nothing of this in Gat out of hell, with one exception: the musical number.\nI'd rate this 3 out of 5 for the love of the series.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
6/10

While there is little main story in this stand-alone expansion, the copy/paste similar activities have returned and that is all you have to do.

I believe the only thing fun in this expansion is playing with the new powers and the big one, flight. In this game you have angelic wings and can fly around. The flying mechanic and ability is the best thing they could have made, but it makes cars and super speed useless.

Sprinting can only get you so far and is probably the last thing you will do before taking to the sky at high speeds once you get it down. The terrain is super hard to navigate with just sprinting alone and overall flying will be the better choice in the end, not that I am complaining.

I loved it but it's only because I am a sucker for wings and flying capabilities.

The activities isn't what made Saints Row great though, the hilarious story missions did and characters, which this has little to none of that besides finding the other minor/returning characters in this new world and  saving them in the end when they get captured.

Otherwise there's not much else to do besides mess around and collect stuff. That is the end goal. I have to say Gat is an awesome character and I loved when they brought him back, but this expansion lacked a lot and should not have been a stand-alone expansion at all.

At most this should have a been a dlc continuing on from the last Saints Row. It would have been perfect...

If you like wings/flying, the activities from Saints Row 4, new guns, new powers, and Gat or Kinzie. I'd say it would be worth buying at full price if that is what you are into.

If not, I'd say wait for the price to drop to like $5 or less because it is not worth the $20.

reviewText: Awsome
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
3.8 out of 5

(No Leather & Lace parody for customization in-game = falling short of 4)


CONS:
Mission design and scripting is absent
Acts I, II, and III trigger too easily and well under 6 hours for gametime
6 hours of gameplay
HUB menu soundbite is irritating
Storyboarding replaces Mission content
Costuming and Individual Customization is stripped out
No licenced Single Track or EP Soundtrack
Most of the added voicing are in the form of fetch items
Doesn't take nasty jabs at Twilight
Leather & Lace absent (Why?! It would have been AWESOME!!)

PROS:
BOOM CHICKA (witty word play on Boomsheeka = 11/10)
Great flight game (think Archeangel from X-men but with Johnny)
7 deadly weapons
Flight has been overhauled
Super powers are back  (re-fleshed as Stomp, Summon, Aura, Blast)
Johnny and Kenzie are back AND playable
No copy-paste Steelport Map
Pokes Event Horizon and WIcked (11/10 awesome.)
Utilizes most recent save to 'guest star' your custom Saint
Worship Aura

This is a bite-sized version of a full game. GOOH has the possibility of being a real gem as a forerunner to SR5. The events in SR4 would inevitably lead to the take over the underworld and depose the Prince of Darkness, right?! Can a Saint reach Sainthood? (Vaguely reference from tatoos in SR3 and 4, so Volition had an idea to start with.)  Can Gat catch the eye of the Big G on borrowed wings? Will the Saint bring fire and brimstone upon the universe?! Who knows.

The content is sufficient enough to urguably price at $20. Wait till it's on sale on Steam. Had it been priced 12.99 I'd say pick it up right now and enjoy. GOOH hovers in a weird area between where it feels more like DLC and less standalone and missed out on being a full release. It takes up what SR does well (weapons, combat style, skyscraper set pieces etc) and cuts out a lot the shortcomings (annoying repetition on NPC 'pickle' phrases) but doesn't supply much more than that.  Mostly filler challenges and some loyalty and side quests and the chance to enjoy flight. BUT in the tradition of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, GOOH also has a musical to enjoy. WOOT!

Be aware of no additional clothing customizations, so you can't dress up as a Grim Reaper or Mistress of the Dark, no licensed soundtrack (just have Michael's 'Thriller' nearby and other pop-horror tunes handy or maybe Meatloaf, Audioslave, Godsmack, Gorillaz, Queens of the Stoneage, Benni Benasi, Pitbull on standby.) No witty references to Elvira, or other pop, zombie, horror, vampire, werewolf culture appear at all.

Had this title recieved a proper numbered sequel budget it could have easily transitioned into a stand alone, spin-off franchise while still maintaining Saints Row status without officially being Saints Row 5 (if they had done what they originally did with SR4, which originally was slated as a SR3 expansion then released as a full game I wouldn't hesitate so much over the lack of what's missing.)

So much potential goes unused because it IS an 'expandalone' DLC.  Just find the Leather & Lace soundtrack on YouTube to play while in game... LOL

reviewText:
I've played through all the saints row games now save for the first one (Can't seem to find it for the pc) and this is by far the shortest.

It kind of feels like they were trying to trim away bits from the game. I don't know why they would do this but, they did.

Don't get me wrong though. I do like the game. Not love, but like.

I would love the game but there's some things that give it bad points. So... I'll make the list of positives and negatives.

Pro:

1. You get to play as Gat.

This is cool since we get to dive into the charicter more. It kind of felt like there was a disconnection from the other charicters in the series other then the boss. This made it so we got to know the charicter more. Which is kinda cool.

2. Get to play as Kenzi (did I spell that right?)

Same as above.

3. Creative weapons.

Self explanitory.

4. Flight. (which is the biggest positive)

The flight mechanics alone in this game (assuming you have your controls set up right) are fantastic in my opinion.
They make the game. I find myself flying around, swooping through wrecked buildings and over lava pits just for the fun of flying. Wishing that flying in saints row 4 was like this. (Maybe a mod could be done to transfer it? Or DLC for a winged flight power in 4?)

The Cons:

1. Short story.

It felt like they rushed it. The story -is- good, but it just seems like they needed more charicter interaction.

2. Shortage of mini-games

The games they do have are fun. But there's a lot of diversity which has gone missing.

3. Teaser of what they could have had in ending.

I'm not going to give it away here, but I'm going to say that after you get some things acomplished, there's a story book telling ending segment that tells a story that would have been better if played through. At first when I saw it I thought Cool! I get to face them to then?" but no. It's only part of a story instead. A small segment. Almost trollish really. I'm -hoping- they add them in through a patch or something but... anyways....

For those of you who have played through it you'll know what I mean. For those who haven't it's a negative point for the moment unless they add it as a not too expensive or free DLC.

4. The settings were hellishly dull (pun intended).

I understand that it's hell and there's not too much you can do with it. They -were- creative with what they had. But... why did they have to spend -all- the time in hell? They couldn't have gone back to the ship? Maybe seen the alien ship some? Had some nightmare dream scenes in other settings to save people from?

The part of 4 that makes it such a negative point is that we have such beautiful flight controls
date:
but enjoying them is hard to do because the scene is always so terrible and... well... hellish.

Over all I give the game 7/10 for the time being depending on what they do with it in the future. Given the right DLC (given it's not too pricey) I may revisit this review.
"

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Gat out of Hell is a standalone expansion for Saints Row 4. Being an expansion it's not to big or long. Story is much shorter and not as good as the other games, and the map is smaller as well. This time the map is in hell, but is the smallest one yet. There's also no homie system, which is a real shame, and no radio at all, which sucks as Saints Row 4 had a good thing going with on foot radio.

You play as either Johny Gat or Kinzie, trying to save the boss (who is carried over if you have Saints Row 3 or 4 installed). Some old characters are back (Dex, Dane Vogul, Viola and Kiki) and the new ones are just as cool (Blackbeard, Vlad, Shakespeare and Satan!) The same humour from the past few Saints Row games is here as well, there's even a musical scene! If you don't like that humour and prefer the serious nature of SR1 and 2 then this is not for you.

You still have superpowers, but now you also have wings! The new hell weapons are pretty cool as well (mostly just reskins of older weapons though), and the new map is pretty cool, despite also being mostly just parts of Stillwater and Steelport with a hellish twist.
6.8/10

reviewText: This game...is the most wonderful thing I have played this year so far. It's everything you'd expect and then some. It's good ol' Saints Row starring Johnny Gat and Kinzie. reviewText:
I'll have to give this a down.  I love the Saint's Row series for the sheer insanity that comes to pass in an open world sandbox style game.  It's like the GTA series without the bad gangsta story lines and stupid moralizing - like the original GTA series in fact.  But this stand-alone isn't a very good look at it.

The setting is, uhm, unique.  Having a Judeo-Christian hell theme was a bold choice and I fully support it.  The mythology of modern religions is very evocative and has some very interesting characters.  But the actual hell-scape is rather small and lacks some of the variability of, say, Dante's Divine Comedy.  Flames are all fine and dandy but give us an ice-scape or an eternal desert, eh?  The very basic demonic soldiery and denizens are also a tad disappointing but they're effective for what they are - just wish it would be more creative in this realm.

The combat is too frantic for me, as well.  Sorry but I was one of those types to invest heavily in Notoriety decomposition upgrades.  I prefer a more relaxed combat pace where I can approach things in a methodical manner.  Having swarms of demonic enemies every two steps put me off on actually doing anything in-game.  And the size of the game world is telling.  Because there is only one type of purchasable good (weapons) that is bought from a vending machine (usually out in the open where demons will gleefully pick you off with cars), there's no easy and ready way of clearing Notoriety.  Which - for me - made combat a chore to slog through instead of something fun to do.

The powers are a retread of Saints Row IV pretty much.  They are quickly gained but it takes a long time to upgrade them and the collectathon to do so isn't as fun as SRIV in my opinion.  It felt like I was just doing the same thing in a smaller space.

Now here's the kicker and what really made me go from 'so-so' to a firm downvote: character customization.  Hey, hey.  Hey Volition?  No one cares about Gat.  Not really.  We care about the Boss.  You know, the player stand-in?  Gat might be your big wet dream but not ours.  If I want to play as Doctor Manhatten with a rocket launcher, well damn it - that's what I want to do.  And throwing the female players a bone in the form of Kinzie only works if SHE IS MENTIONED IN THE CUTSCENES.  Or is playable at the end boss.  Or, well, anything takes into account her existence.

So, this is a 'not recommended' on my end.  It's fun but that fun is tempered with a huge helping of 'same old' from SRIV, the lack of anything really pulling me back to the game, lack of customization and too-frantic and not much fun constant combat - as well as a bit of a missed opportunity in the setting.  Wait till the price drops by half or more and then give it a go.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
3.8 out of 5

(No Leather & Lace parody for customization in-game = falling short of 4)


CONS:
Mission design and scripting is absent
Acts I, II, and III trigger too easily and well under 6 hours for gametime
6 hours of gameplay
HUB menu soundbite is irritating
Storyboarding replaces Mission content
Costuming and Individual Customization is stripped out
No licenced Single Track or EP Soundtrack
Most of the added voicing are in the form of fetch items
Doesn't take nasty jabs at Twilight
Leather & Lace absent (Why?! It would have been AWESOME!!)

PROS:
BOOM CHICKA (witty word play on Boomsheeka = 11/10)
Great flight game (think Archeangel from X-men but with Johnny)
7 deadly weapons
Flight has been overhauled
Super powers are back  (re-fleshed as Stomp, Summon, Aura, Blast)
Johnny and Kenzie are back AND playable
No copy-paste Steelport Map
Pokes Event Horizon and WIcked (11/10 awesome.)
Utilizes most recent save to 'guest star' your custom Saint
Worship Aura

This is a bite-sized version of a full game. GOOH has the possibility of being a real gem as a forerunner to SR5. The events in SR4 would inevitably lead to the take over the underworld and depose the Prince of Darkness, right?! Can a Saint reach Sainthood? (Vaguely reference from tatoos in SR3 and 4, so Volition had an idea to start with.)  Can Gat catch the eye of the Big G on borrowed wings? Will the Saint bring fire and brimstone upon the universe?! Who knows.

The content is sufficient enough to urguably price at $20. Wait till it's on sale on Steam. Had it been priced 12.99 I'd say pick it up right now and enjoy. GOOH hovers in a weird area between where it feels more like DLC and less standalone and missed out on being a full release. It takes up what SR does well (weapons, combat style, skyscraper set pieces etc) and cuts out a lot the shortcomings (annoying repetition on NPC 'pickle' phrases) but doesn't supply much more than that.  Mostly filler challenges and some loyalty and side quests and the chance to enjoy flight. BUT in the tradition of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, GOOH also has a musical to enjoy. WOOT!

Be aware of no additional clothing customizations, so you can't dress up as a Grim Reaper or Mistress of the Dark, no licensed soundtrack (just have Michael's 'Thriller' nearby and other pop-horror tunes handy or maybe Meatloaf, Audioslave, Godsmack, Gorillaz, Queens of the Stoneage, Benni Benasi, Pitbull on standby.) No witty references to Elvira, or other pop, zombie, horror, vampire, werewolf culture appear at all.

Had this title recieved a proper numbered sequel budget it could have easily transitioned into a stand alone, spin-off franchise while still maintaining Saints Row status without officially being Saints Row 5 (if they had done what they originally did with SR4, which originally was slated as a SR3 expansion then released as a full game I wouldn't hesitate so much over the lack of what's missing.)

So much potential goes unused because it IS an 'expandalone' DLC.  Just find the Leather & Lace soundtrack on YouTube to play while in game... LOL

reviewText:
I've played through all the saints row games now save for the first one (Can't seem to find it for the pc) and this is by far the shortest.

It kind of feels like they were trying to trim away bits from the game. I don't know why they would do this but, they did.

Don't get me wrong though. I do like the game. Not love, but like.

I would love the game but there's some things that give it bad points. So... I'll make the list of positives and negatives.

Pro:

1. You get to play as Gat.

This is cool since we get to dive into the charicter more. It kind of felt like there was a disconnection from the other charicters in the series other then the boss. This made it so we got to know the charicter more. Which is kinda cool.

2. Get to play as Kenzi (did I spell that right?)

Same as above.

3. Creative weapons.

Self explanitory.

4. Flight. (which is the biggest positive)

The flight mechanics alone in this game (assuming you have your controls set up right) are fantastic in my opinion.
They make the game. I find myself flying around, swooping through wrecked buildings and over lava pits just for the fun of flying. Wishing that flying in saints row 4 was like this. (Maybe a mod could be done to transfer it? Or DLC for a winged flight power in 4?)

The Cons:

1. Short story.

It felt like they rushed it. The story -is- good, but it just seems like they needed more charicter interaction.

2. Shortage of mini-games

The games they do have are fun. But there's a lot of diversity which has gone missing.

3. Teaser of what they could have had in ending.

I'm not going to give it away here, but I'm going to say that after you get some things acomplished, there's a story book telling ending segment that tells a story that would have been better if played through. At first when I saw it I thought Cool! I get to face them to then?" but no. It's only part of a story instead. A small segment. Almost trollish really. I'm -hoping- they add them in through a patch or something but... anyways....

For those of you who have played through it you'll know what I mean. For those who haven't it's a negative point for the moment unless they add it as a not too expensive or free DLC.

4. The settings were hellishly dull (pun intended).

I understand that it's hell and there's not too much you can do with it. They -were- creative with what they had. But... why did they have to spend -all- the time in hell? They couldn't have gone back to the ship? Maybe seen the alien ship some? Had some nightmare dream scenes in other settings to save people from?

The part of 4 that makes it such a negative point is that we have such beautiful flight controls
date:
but enjoying them is hard to do because the scene is always so terrible and... well... hellish.

Over all I give the game 7/10 for the time being depending on what they do with it in the future. Given the right DLC (given it's not too pricey) I may revisit this review.
"

reviewText: SR: Gat out of Hell is more of the same game we've all come to know and love, but with enough changed to make the game feel like a genuine addition, not just a reskin with an attempt to make money before releasing a true sequel. The powers are back, but feel almost entirely different, aside from sprinting, but hey, how different can you make running, with the new flying system actually living up to its name. The flight mechanic is a big highlight in the game, with enough speed to make up for no summonable vehicles, nimble enough not to be frustrating, and just bad ♥♥♥ enough to feel satisfying using it for the majority of the short game. Guns, while limited, are still satisfying, with a few hidden gems clearly having been lovingly made. You'll love Gat and Kinzie's foray into the infernal plane if you can get past the fact that this isn't a true successor to the Saint's Row series; meaning that it's not meant to have all the bells and whistles. With Gat getting some well deserved love as well as Kinzie, this should be the balm to that itch you got from SRIV from banging your entire team.

reviewText:
Well, this was kind of disappointing.  I love Saints Row!  The consistent original style and fun gameplay of the entire franchise has been nothing short of astonishing and ironically. in some ways even surpasses the Grand Theft Auto franchise (the series that Saints Row was initially dismissed by many for it's similarities), despite Saints Row significantly smaller budget and development timeframe.  Saints Row IV was my second favorite in the franchise, behind Saints Row II and Kinzie Kenzington (my favorite character in the franchise) is a playable character in this game, which picks up after the events of Saints Row IV, so I had some high hopes for this game, while also remaining cautious in my expectations due to it's mere $20 price tag.  I wasn't expecting anything spectacular and yet I was still disappointed.

I've played Saints Row IV to death and I was eager to play a brand new entry in the franchise, what I found was basically the same game, playing like a total conversion mod but with half of the features in IV removed.  Why the hell is there absolutely no radio in this game?  Why are no clothing stores or customizable outfits of any kind?  Why is the map so much smaller than it has ever been in any other Saints Row game?  Why giving the game a plot when almost the entire game consists of city takeover" side quests that have absolutely nothing to do with the plot?  These are only some of the many questions you'll end up asking yourself as you play this game.

Many fans were initially skeptical of SRIV's quality before it was released after news broke that it was originally supposed to be DLC for Saints Row III
date: and they were eventually proven wrong when SRIV turned out to written and developed well enough to actually justify it's status as a stand-alone title; But be warned
recommended: this is the real deal!  A stand-alone Saints Row game that really should have been DLC for Saints Row IV!  Even with it's $20 price tag
hoursPlayed: it's still lacking enough content and plot to justify it as a stand-alone title in the franchise.\n\nIn short
voteText: if you're new to Saints Row or you're not a die-hard fan
helpfulPercent: don't buy it.  However
votesHelpful: if you're a Saints Row fanatic like me
votesTotal: I'd recommend it
votesFunny: but wait until it's on sale for $5 or lower
commentsCount:
because that's what most DLC should be worth and this is just DLC pretending to be it's own game.

As much as this pains me:
5/10"

reviewText:
Lots of fun for twenty bucks.  Winged flight is excellent and should (somehow) remain in the series.

Story is barebones and pretty much all missions are just hell versions of the normal diversions you're used to in the Saints Row universe.  With all of the work that obviously went into this game, it's a crying shame that more of it wasn't utilized in a meaningful way.  It may be a glorified DLC, but there is just SO MUCH POTENTIAL here for something MUCH greater.

If they were to make a fully-hellified honest-to-Satan jam-packed feature-sized version with real missions, character customization, and the whole nine yards, I would buy the hell out of it at full price.

As it stands, you're kind of getting a third for a third.

Still recommended, though.
